question: Our reason is always deceived by changing [MASK], nothing can fix the finite between the two infinites, which at once enclose and fly from it.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: We may not then look for certainty or stability.
next_sentence: If this be once well understood I think that we shall rest, each in the state wherein nature has placed him.

question: But as a reminder we ought to [MASK] to ourselves to do something distasteful; we then excuse ourselves that we have something else to do, and thus remember our duty.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: If we like a book we read it, when we should be doing something else.
next_sentence: Sneezing absorbs all the faculties of the soul, as do certain bodily functions, but we do not draw therefrom the same conclusions against the greatness of man, because it is against his will.

question: But after all they have not been [MASK] hidden, since they have become known.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: When I see some of these in history they please me much.
next_sentence: And though all has been done to hide them that could be done, the little whereby they have appeared has spoiled all, for what was finest in them was the desire to hide them.

question: It had not then been just that he should appear in a manner plainly divine, and wholly capable of convincing all men, but neither had it been just that he should come in so hidden a manner as not to be recognised of those who [MASK] sought him.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: Not thus willed he to appear in his gentle advent, because since so many men make themselves unworthy of his mercy, he willed to leave them deprived of the good which they refuse.
next_sentence: He has willed to reveal himself wholly to these, and thus willing to appear openly to those who seek him with their whole heart, and to hide himself from those who fly him with all their heart, he has so tempered the knowledge of himself as to give signs of himself visible to those who seek him, and obscure to those who seek him not.

question: Other religions, as those of heathendom, are more popular since they consist only in externals, but they have no [MASK] on the educated.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: What men could scarcely know by their greatest light, this Religion has taught to babes.
next_sentence: A purely intellectual religion would be more adapted to the educated, but it would be of no use to the people.

question: They declare in putting it forth to the world that it is a foolishness, stultitiam, and then you complain that they do not [MASK] it.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: Who then will blame Christians for not being able to give a reason for their faith; those who profess a religion for which they cannot give a reason?
next_sentence: Were they to prove it they would not keep their word, it is in lacking proof that they are not lacking in sense.--Yes, but although this excuses those who offer it as such, and takes away from them the blame of putting it forth without reason, it does not excuse those who receive it.--Let us then examine this point, and say "God is, or he is not."

question: Here is a care [MASK] of occupying this great soul, and taking away from him every other thought of the mind.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: His whole thoughts are fixed on taking it as it falls from the pent-house, to win a chase; and you cannot ask that he should think on his business, having this other affair in hand.
next_sentence: This man, born to know the Universe, to judge of all things, to rule a State, is altogether occupied and filled with the business of catching a hare.

question: No, they are [MASK] either real or typical.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: Are they obviously typical?
next_sentence: But the first set, which bar a literal interpretation, prove that the whole are typical.

question: Hence we may judge concerning those who live without thinking of the ultimate [MASK] of life, who allow themselves to be guided by their inclinations and their pleasures without thought or disquiet, and, as if they could annihilate eternity by turning their minds from it, consider only how they may make themselves happy for the moment.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: Nothing is more clear than this, and therefore by all principles of reason the conduct of men is most unreasonable if they do not alter their course.
next_sentence: Yet this eternity exists; and death the gate of eternity, which threatens them every hour, must in a short while infallibly reduce them to the dread necessity of being through eternity either nothing or miserable, without knowing which of these eternities is for ever prepared for them.

question: Nothing makes us understand better the absurdity of a false sonnet than to consider nature and the pattern, and then to imagine a woman or a [MASK] constructed on that pattern.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: Not that the bad is unique, for there are many; but every bad sonnet, for instance, on whatever false pattern it is constructed, is exactly like a woman dressed on that pattern.
next_sentence: When a natural discourse paints a passion or an effect, we feel in our mind the truth of what we read, which was there before, though we did not know it, and we are inclined to love him who makes us feel it.

question: The pleasure of [MASK] to-morrow among his friends that he has played better than another.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: But can you say what object he has in all this?
next_sentence: Thus others sweat in their closets to prove to the learned world that they have solved an algebraical problem hitherto insoluble, while many more expose themselves to the greatest perils, in my judgment as foolishly, for the glory of taking a town.

question: Hence it comes that each man [MASK] that he is all to all.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: Every one is all in all to himself, for he being dead, all is dead to him.
next_sentence: We ought not to judge of nature by ourselves, but by it.

question: To [MASK] death out of danger, and not in danger, for we must be men.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: the charm is worked.
next_sentence: Sudden death is the only thing to fear, therefore confessors live in the houses of the great.

question: We [MASK] that it roust be something immaterial.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: The blood?
next_sentence: I can easily conceive a man without hands, feet, head, for it is only experience which teaches us that the head is more necessary than the feet.

question: Of these two scientific infinities, that of greatness is the most [MASK] to the senses, and therefore few persons have made pretensions to universal knowledge.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: But we make some apparently final to the reason, just as in regard to material things we call that an indivisible point beyond which our senses can no longer perceive any thing, though by its nature this also is infinitely divisible.
next_sentence: "I will discourse of the all," said Democritus.

question: Every opinion may be held in preference to life, of which the [MASK] seems so strong and so natural.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: Ferox gens, nullam esse vitam sine armis rati. They love death rather than peace, other men love death rather than war.
next_sentence: Thoughts.--All is one, all is diverse.

question: Then let us make it our study to think well, for this is the starting-point of [MASK].
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: By this must we raise ourselves, not by space or duration which we cannot fill.
next_sentence: The greatness of man is great in that he knows he is miserable.

question: The same is often true in other [MASK].
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: Another said to me that he was still fearful, whereupon I thought that these two together would make one good man, and that each was so far wanting in that he had not the feelings of the other.
next_sentence: The knowledge of God is very far from the love of him.

question: All err the more dangerously because they follow each a truth, their fault is not that they follow an [MASK], but that they do not follow another truth.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: But the ancient Church did not postulate the future Church, and did not regard her, as we postulate and regard the ancient.
next_sentence: That which hinders us in comparing what formerly took place in the Church with what we now see, is that we are wont to regard Saint Athanasius or Saint Theresa and others as crowned with glory, and acting in regard to us as gods.

question: Much that is [MASK] passes without contradiction.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: Much that is certain is contradicted.
next_sentence: Contradiction is not a mark of falsehood, nor the want of contradiction a mark of truth.

question: In things of the flesh lust reigns especially, in men of [MASK] curiosity especially, in wisdom pride especially.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: God must reign over all, and all must be referred to him.
next_sentence: Not that a man may not boast of wealth or knowledge, but there is no room for pride, for in granting that a man is learned there will be no difficulty in proving to him that he is wrong to be proud.

question: If doctrine regulate miracles, [MASK] are useless for doctrine.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: ; and Jesus Christ one.
next_sentence: If miracles regulate....  Objection to the rule.  Discrimination between times.

question: Before him the world [MASK] in a false peace.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: "I came to bring war," he says, and to inform them of this war, "I came to bring fire and the sword."
next_sentence: The exterior must be joined to the interior to obtain aught from God, that is to say, we must kneel, pray with the lips, etc., in order that proud man, who would not submit himself to God, should now be subject to the creature.

question: It is the same with knowledge, of which [MASK] deprives us.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: Weakness.--The whole employment of men is to gain wealth; yet they have no title to show that they justly possess it but human caprice, nor have they power to hold it securely.
next_sentence: We are incapable both of truth and of goodness.

question: Nature is permanent, and continues in one [MASK]; he is fleeting and mortal.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: For nature has a twofold infinity, he is finite and limited.
next_sentence: All things fail and change each instant, he sees them only as they pass, they have their beginning and end, he conceives neither the one nor the other.

question: Just as if a man boasted that he could prevent death, no one would believe him because there is no [MASK] of this.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: Were there no remedy for any evil, and were all diseases incurable, it is impossible that men should ever have imagined that they could give remedies, and still more impossible that so many others should have believed those who boasted that they had them.
next_sentence: But as there are a number of remedies which are approved as true, even by the knowledge of the greatest men, the belief of men is thereby inclined; and since the thing was known to be possible, it has been therefore concluded that it was.

question: Four lands of persons: [MASK] without knowledge, knowledge without zeal, neither knowledge nor zeal, zeal and knowledge.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: That they were disturbing the peace, that they were creating a schism, etc.
next_sentence: The first three condemned him, the last absolved him, were excommunicated by the Church and yet saved the Church.

question: And thus, when in future they are condemned, they will [MASK] ad hominem that they are unjust, and thus will refute their judgment.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: In corrupting the bishops and the Sorbonne, if they have not had the advantage of making their judgment just, they have had that of making their judges unjust.
next_sentence: But that does no good.

question: We must [MASK] those whose feelings are humane and tender.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: For concupiscence is the source of all our movements, and humanity, etc.
next_sentence: That epigram about the two one-eyed people is valueless, for it brings them no consolation, and only gives a point to the author's glory.

question: We will therefore [MASK] what she has to say on questions within her powers.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: But perhaps the subject goes beyond the reach of reason.
next_sentence: If there be anything to which her own interest must have made her apply herself most seriously, it is the search after her sovereign good.

question: Thought is then in its nature [MASK] and incomparable.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: how foolish it is!
next_sentence: It must have strange defects to be despicable, but it has these, and so nothing is more ridiculous.

question: Archimedes without worldly [MASK] would have had the same reverence.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: They are seen of God and the angels, and not by the bodily eye, nor by the curious spirit; God suffices them.
next_sentence: He fought no battles for the eye to gaze on, but he left his discoveries to all minds.

question: For what in animals is nature we call in man [MASK], whereby we recognise that his nature being now like that of animals he is fallen from a better nature which once was his.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: The greatness of man is so evident that it is even proved by his littleness.
next_sentence: For what man ever was unhappy at not being a king, save a discrowned king?

question: There is one only heresy, which is differently explained in the schools and in the [MASK].
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: The evil having been done of patting these things in French, we ought to do the good of condemning them.
next_sentence: On confessions and absolutions without signs of regret. God looks at the heart alone, the Church looks at outward actions; God absolves as soon as he sees penitence in the heart, the Church when she sees it in works.

question: What have they [MASK] of her substance?
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: We will hear the rulers of the world on this matter.
next_sentence: Have they been more happy in fixing her seat?

question: Man is naturally [MASK] and incredulous, timid and rash.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: Contraries.
next_sentence: A corrupt nature.--Man does not act by reason, which constitutes his essence.

question: State super vias et [MASK] de semitis antiquis, et ambulate in eis.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: It is of importance to kings and princes to be supposed pious, and therefore they must take you for their confessors.
next_sentence: Et dixerunt: Non ambulabimus, sed post cogitationem nostram ibimus. They have said to the nations: Come to us, we will follow the opinions of the new authors, reason shall be our guide, we will be as the other nations who follow each their natural light.

question: Let not people think of him as an orator, unless oratory be in question, then let them [MASK] of it.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: Ne quid nimis, for fear some one quality gain the mastery and stamp the man.
next_sentence: No man passes in the world as an expert in verse unless he hang out the sign of a poet, a mathematician, etc.

question: Reason would never submit if it did not judge that on some occasions submission is a [MASK].
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: Saint Augustine.
next_sentence: It is then right that it should submit, when it judges that it ought to submit.

question: It is then right that it should [MASK], when it judges that it ought to submit.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: Reason would never submit if it did not judge that on some occasions submission is a duty.
next_sentence: Piety is different from superstition.

question: Therefore faith is not in our power, like the works of the law, and it is [MASK] us in another way.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: no, but by that of faith.
next_sentence: Faith is a gift of God, do not suppose us to say it is a gift of reason.

question: So that they, who were of all nations in the world the least [MASK] to the suspicion of favouring us, the most scrupulous and most zealous that can be named for their law and their prophets, have kept the records incorrupt.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: But this people deceived by the poor and ignominious advent of the Messiah have been his most cruel enemies.
next_sentence: Therefore the prophecies have a hidden and spiritual sense, which this people hated, under the carnal sense which they loved.

question: So soon, then, as we see a [MASK] we should at once either acquiesce or have signal marks against it.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: They would have sinned in not excluding those who denied God, and would also have sinned in excluding those who denied him not.
next_sentence: We must see if it denies either a God, or Jesus Christ, or the Church.

question: There must be motions of [MASK], not from merit, but from grace, and after having passed through abasement.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: There must be motions of abasement, yet not from nature, but from penitence, not to rest in them, but to go onward to greatness.
next_sentence: This double nature of man is so evident, that there are those who have imagined us to have two souls.

question: Had it been his will to overcome the stubbornness of the most hardened, he could have rendered them unable to doubt the truth of his essence, in revealing himself manifestly to them as he will appear at the last day, amid thunderings and lightnings, and so great a convulsion of nature, that the dead will rise again, and the [MASK] shall see him.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: But men render themselves so unworthy of it, that it is just that God should refuse to some because of their hardness of heart what he grants to others out of a mercy not their due.
next_sentence: Not thus willed he to appear in his gentle advent, because since so many men make themselves unworthy of his mercy, he willed to leave them deprived of the good which they refuse.

question: Otherwise they would not follow it though it were the custom, for our only desire is to be [MASK] to reason or to justice.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: Montaigne was wrong: custom should only be followed because it is custom, and not because it is reasonable or just; but most men follow it for the simple reason that they think it just.
next_sentence: Without this, custom would pass for tyranny, but the empire of reason and justice is no more tyrannical than that of choice.

question: Thus his very infirmities proves [MASK]'s greatness.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: It is therefore little to know ourselves little, and it is great to know ourselves little.
next_sentence: They are the infirmities of a great lord, of a discrowned king.

question: But there are those who have not thus the power of preventing thought, and who think the more the more we [MASK] them.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: Thus false religions are preserved, and the true also, as regards many people.
next_sentence: These get rid of false religions, and of the true also, if they do not find solid reasons.

question: Whatever is not made on this pattern [MASK] those who have good taste.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: Whatever is formed on this pattern delights us, whether house, song, discourse, verse, prose, woman, birds, rivers, trees, rooms, dresses, etc.
next_sentence: And as there is a perfect relation between a song and a house which are made on a good pattern, because they are like this unique pattern, though each after its kind, there is also a perfect relation between things made on a bad pattern.

question: They will no doubt fight till the stronger party gets the better of the weaker, and a dominant [MASK] is constituted.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: Let us suppose then we see men beginning to form a society.
next_sentence: But so soon as this is once settled, the masters not wishing that the strife should continue, declare that the power in their hands shall be transmitted as they please, some placing it in the choice of the people, others in the succession of birth, etc.

question: It is so natural and so delicate a representation of the passions that it moves them, and makes them spring up in our heart, above all that of love, [MASK] when it is represented as very chaste and very honourable.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: All great amusements are dangerous to the Christian life, but among all those which the world has invented none is so much to be feared as the theatre.
next_sentence: For the more innocent it seems to innocent souls, the more are they capable of being touched by it; its violence pleases our self-love, which at once forms the desire of causing the same effects which we see so well represented, and at the same time we make for ourselves a conscience founded on the honour of the feelings which we see there.

question: The [MASK] of riches is to be given liberally.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: The pleasure of the great is to be able to make people happy.
next_sentence: The property of each thing should be sought out.

question: Its morality and happiness are ridiculous in the tradition of the people, but admirable in that of their [MASK].
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: The Jewish religion must be differently regarded in the tradition of the sacred books and in the tradition of the people.
next_sentence: The foundation is admirable, it is the most ancient book in the world, and the most authentic, and whereas Mahomet, in order to ensure the lasting existence of his book forbade men to read it, Moses with the same object commanded everyone to read his.

question: We judge that [MASK] do well what they do.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: Have we then no rule?
next_sentence: Is there no rule whereby to judge men?

question: How many kingdoms [MASK] nothing of us!
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: It is not well to have all we want.
next_sentence: The eternal silence of these infinite spaces alarms me.

question: In playing tennis, two men play with the same [MASK], but one places it better.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: Let no one say I have said nothing new, the disposition of my matter is new.
next_sentence: It might as truly be said that my words have been used before.

question: ; he did not see the [MASK] of chances, which demonstrates that we must do so.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: Saint Augustine saw that we labour for an uncertainty, at sea, in a battle, etc.
next_sentence: Montaigne saw that we are disgusted at a distorted mind, and that custom can do all things, but he did not see the reason of that effect.

question: But we do not [MASK] to be mistaken, and that perhaps arises from the fact that man by nature cannot see everything, and that by nature he cannot be mistaken in the side he looks at, since what we apprehend by our senses is always true.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: Now, no one is vexed at not seeing every thing.
next_sentence: I passed a long time in the study of the abstract sciences, and was much discouraged at finding how few were my fellow-students.

question: The reason therefore that some practical men are not mathematical is that they cannot at all turn their [MASK] to mathematical premisses.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: And practical men would be mathematicians if they could turn their eyes to the premisses of mathematics to which they are unaccustomed.
next_sentence: But the reason that mathematicians are not practical is that they do not see what is before them, and that, accustomed to the precise and distinct statements of mathematics and not reasoning till they have well examined and arranged their premisses, they are lost in practical life wherein the premisses do not admit of such arrangement, being scarcely seen, indeed they are felt rather than seen, and there is great difficulty in causing them to be felt by those who do not of themselves perceive them.

question: Compare not thyself with [MASK], but with me.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: At the Last Supper he gave himself in communion as one about to die; to the disciples at Emmaus as one risen from the dead; to the whole Church as one ascended into heaven.
next_sentence: If thou findest me not in those with whom thou comparest thyself, thou comparest thyself with him that is abominable.

question: For what man ever was unhappy at not being a king, save a discrowned [MASK]?
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: For what in animals is nature we call in man littleness, whereby we recognise that his nature being now like that of animals he is fallen from a better nature which once was his.
next_sentence: Was Paulus Emilius unhappy at being no longer consul?

question: Both hypotheses are [MASK]; for it is not possible to mistake a man raised from the dead ....
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: The apostles were either deceived or deceivers.
next_sentence: While Jesus Christ was with them, his presence might sustain them, but after that, what gave them force to act if he did not appear to them?

question: As we know it to be false that [MASK] are finite, it must therefore be true that there is an infinity in number, but what this is we know not.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: We know that there is an infinite, but are ignorant of its nature.
next_sentence: It can neither be odd nor even, for the addition of an unit can make no change in the nature of number; yet it is a number, and every number is either odd or even, at least this is understood of every finite number.

question: But he may perhaps [MASK] to know at least the parts with which he has proportionate relation.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: How can a part know the whole?
next_sentence: But the parts of the world are so linked and related, that I think it impossible to know one without another, or without the whole.

question: All that is brought to perfection by [MASK] perishes also by progress.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: We only change our fancies.
next_sentence: All that has been weak can never be absolutely strong.

question: Here is a succession of men for the space of four thousand years, who without interruption or variation, [MASK] one another in foretelling the same event.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: But in this case there is much more.
next_sentence: Here is a whole people announcing it, existing for four thousand years, to testify in a body their certainty, from which they cannot be diverted by all the threatenings and persecutions brought to bear against them; this is in a far greater degree important.

question: They all seek their satisfaction, and differ only in the object wherein they place it; they call those their [MASK] who hinder them, etc.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: The ordinary life of man is like that of the saints.
next_sentence: God then has shown the power which he has to give invisible possessions, by the power which he has shown over things visible.

question: These things took [MASK] under the conditions of a nature quite different to our own, transcending our present capacity.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: We cannot conceive the glorious state of Adam, nor the nature of his sin, nor the transmission of it to us.
next_sentence: The knowledge of all this would be of no use in helping us to escape from it, and all we need know is that we are miserable, corrupt, separate from God, but ransomed by Jesus Christ, and of this we have on earth wonderful proofs.

question: But can you say what [MASK] he has in all this?
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: Dancing.--We must think where to place our feet.
next_sentence: The pleasure of boasting to-morrow among his friends that he has played better than another.

question: and who has told us that the hen may not form the germ as [MASK] as the cock?
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: What distinguishes these outwardly from others?
next_sentence: What have they to say against the resurrection, or against the child-bearing of the Virgin?

question: The certain [MASK] of ruining a just cause has been to get it recommended to these men by their near relatives.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: The man of greatest probity can not be judge in his own cause; I know some who that they may not fall into this self love are, out of opposition, thoroughly unjust.
next_sentence: Justice and truth are two such subtle points, that our instruments are too blunt to touch them accurately.

question: Ne quid nimis, for fear some one [MASK] gain the mastery and stamp the man.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: I would rather that none of his qualities should be recognised till you meet them, or have occasion to avail yourself of them.
next_sentence: Let not people think of him as an orator, unless oratory be in question, then let them think of it.

question: Nothing more astonishes me than to [MASK] that men are not astonished at their own weakness.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: The eternal silence of these infinite spaces alarms me.
next_sentence: They act seriously, and every one follows his own mode of life, not because it is, as a fact, good to follow, being the custom, but as if each man knew certainly where are reason and justice.

question: Justice without power is unavailing, power without justice is [MASK].
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: Justice, Power.--It is just that what is just should be obeyed, it is of necessity that what is strongest should be obeyed.
next_sentence: Justice without power is gainsaid, because the wicked always exist, power without justice is condemned.

question: At any rate the counter-charm was incomplete, as the child's feeble health remained feeble to the [MASK].
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: This made a great impression on his son, who in the "Thoughts" employs an ingenious argument to prove that wonders wrought by the invocation of the devil are not, in the proper sense of the term, miracles.
next_sentence: Intellectually, Blaise Pascal grew rapidly to the stature and strength of a giant; his genius showing itself mainly in the direction of mathematics; at the age of fifteen his studies on conic sections were thought worthy to be read before the most scientific men of Paris, and in after years of agonizing pain mathematical research alone was able to calm him, and distract his mind from himself.

question: The [MASK] will be ignorant of their virtues and the reprobate of the greatness of their crimes.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: Jesus Christ would not be slain without the forms of justice, for it is much more ignominious to die by justice than by an unjust sedition.
next_sentence: "Lord, when saw we thee an hungered or athirst?"

question: All this is [MASK], but there is no contradiction.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: But if miracles are true we cannot persuade men of all doctrine, for that will not come to pass: Si angelus....  Rule. We must judge of doctrine by miracles, we must judge of miracles by doctrine.
next_sentence: For we must distinguish the times.

question: He that will save his soul shall [MASK] it.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: What advantageth it a man that he gain the whole world and lose his own soul?
next_sentence: I am not come to destroy the law, but to fulfil.

question: To [MASK] against those who plunged too deep into science.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: As when a man speaks of the vulgar error that the moon is the cause of all, we never fail to say that Salomon de Tultie says, that when we know not the truth of a matter, it is well there should be a common error, etc; which is the thought above.
next_sentence: Descartes.

question: Must we slay in [MASK] that the wicked may cease to be?
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: They allow lust free play, and restrict scruples, whereas they should do the exact contrary.
next_sentence: This is to make two wicked instead of one.

question: For if in all these matters nothing true had ever taken place, nothing of them had ever been [MASK]; and so instead of concluding that there are no true miracles, because so many are false, we must on the contrary say that there are certainly true miracles because there are false, and that the false only exist because some are true.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: It is the same with prophecies, miracles, divination by dreams, casting lots, etc.
next_sentence: We must reason in the same way about Religion, for it would not be possible that men should have imagined so many false religions had there not been one that is true.

question: What a confusion of judgment is that, by which every one puts himself above all the rest of the world, and loves his own advantage and the duration of his [MASK] or his life above those of all others.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: She would be displeasing if she were not deceived.
next_sentence: DIVERSION.   Diversion.--When I have set myself now and then to consider the various distractions of men, the toils and dangers to which they expose themselves in the court or the camp, whence arise so many quarrels and passions, such daring and often such evil exploits, etc., I have discovered that all the misfortunes of men arise from one thing only, that they are unable to stay quietly in their own chamber.

question: We ought to be much obliged to those who [MASK] us of our faults, for they mortify us, they teach us we have been despised, they do not prevent our being so in the future, for we have many other faults which are despicable.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: Then say none.
next_sentence: They prepare for us the exercise of correction, and freedom from a fault.

question: That is what makes men sober or drunken, soldiers, [MASK], etc.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: How much this man drinks, how little that man!
next_sentence: Glory.--Admiration spoils everything from infancy.

question: That he has established them only for their [MASK].
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
next_sentence: Micah, admirably, vi.

question: We ought not to [MASK] them except where it may be serviceable, but it does them harm.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: To begin by pitying unbelievers, they are miserable enough by their condition.
next_sentence: The arrangement. A letter of advice to a friend to lead him to seek, and he will answer: What is the good of seeking, since nothing comes to light.--Then to answer him: "Do not despair."

question: He only is our true good, and since we have left him, it is strange that there is nothing in nature which has not served to take his place; neither the stars, nor heaven, earth, the elements, plants, cabbages, leeks, animals, insects, calves, serpents, fever, pestilence, war, famine, [MASK], adultery, incest.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: This desire, and this weakness cry aloud to us that there was once in man a true happiness, of which there now remains to him but the mark and the empty trace, which he vainly tries to fill from all that surrounds him, seeking from things absent the succour he finds not in things present; and these are all inadequate, because this infinite void can only be filled by an infinite and immutable object, that is to say, only by God himself.
next_sentence: And since he has lost the true good, all things can equally appear good to him, even his own destruction, though so contrary to God, to reason, and to the whole course of nature.

question: In [MASK] offence at a blow, or in desiring glory so strongly.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
next_sentence: But it is very desirable, on account of the other essential goods which are joined to it, and a man who has received a blow without resenting it is overwhelmed with abuse and indignity.

question: Thus the clear prediction of the time, and the obscure intimation of the blessings, deceives only the [MASK].
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: By this means the wicked, mistaking the promised for material blessings, have gone astray, in spite of clear indications of the time, and the good have not gone astray; for the interpretation of the promised blessings depends on the heart, wont to call that good which it loves, but the interpretation of the promised time does not depend on the heart.
next_sentence: If Jesus Christ had come only for sanctification, the whole of Scripture and all things would tend to this end, and it would be easy to convince unbelievers.

question: For even if the king have pardoned a man, it is necessary that it should be ratified; but if the parliament ratifies without the king, or refuses to [MASK] on the order of the king, it is no more the parliament of the king, but a revolutionary body.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: He associates her with this power as kings their parliaments; but if she binds or looses without God, she is no more the Church, as in the case of parliament.
next_sentence: The Church teaches and God inspires, both infallibly.

question: We are not here dealing with the light [MASK] of a stranger, that we should thus treat it; but with that which concerns ourselves and our all.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: But indeed I will tell them what I have often said, that such carelessness is intolerable.
next_sentence: The immortality of the soul is a matter of so great moment to us, it touches us so deeply, that we must have lost all feeling if we are careless of the truth about it.

question: It distinguishes for me the [MASK] condition with a sufficient condition, the union is necessary, but not sufficient.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: Because my body without my soul would not make the body of a man, then my soul united to any matter whatsoever would make my body.
next_sentence: The left arm is not the right.

question: The one depends on the other, and one [MASK] to the other.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: Infinite capacity is needed for both, and it seems to me that whoever shall have understood the ultimate principles of existence might also attain to the knowledge of the infinite.
next_sentence: Extremes meet and reunite by virtue of their distance, to find each other in God, and in God alone.

question: Among all their errors this doubtless is the one which most proves them to be fools and blind, and in which it is most easy to confound them by the first gleam of [MASK] sense, and by our natural feelings.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: But if any bring to the task perfect sincerity and a true desire to meet with truth, I despair not of their satisfaction, nor of their being convinced of so divine a Religion by the proofs which I have here gathered up, and have set forth in somewhat the following order....  Before entering upon the proofs of the Christian Religion, I find it necessary to set forth the unfairness of men who live indifferent to the search for truth in a matter which is so important to them, and which touches them so nearly.
next_sentence: For it is not to be doubted that this life endures but for an instant, that the state of death is eternal, whatever may be its nature, and that thus all our actions and all our thoughts must take such different courses according to the state of that eternity, as to render it impossible to take a single step with sense and judgment, save in view of that point which ought to be our end and aim.

question: If there was ever a time in which it were necessary to [MASK] profession of two contraries, it is when we are reproached for omitting one.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: We must begin with that; without that we understand nothing and all is heretical; in the same way we must even add at the close of each truth that the opposite truth is to be remembered.
next_sentence: Therefore the Jesuits and the Jansenists are wrong in concealing them, but the Jansenists most, for the Jesuits have better made profession of the two.

question: Unless they give up probability their good [MASK] are as little holy as the bad.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: To him who had not on the wedding garment, the same.
next_sentence: For they are founded on human authority, and thus if they are more just they will be more reasonable, but not more holy, they take after the wild stock on which they are graffed.

question: The time of the first advent was [MASK], the time of the second is not so, because the first was to be secret, the second must be glorious, and so manifest that even his enemies will recognise it.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: Therefore he will not subject them himself.
next_sentence: But as his first coming was to be obscure, and to be known only of those who searched the Scriptures....

question: In the same way that we injure the understanding we injure the [MASK] also.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: How foolish is painting, which draws admiration by the resemblance of things of which we do not admire the originals.
next_sentence: The feelings and the understanding are formed by society, and are perverted by society.

question: For the most part we [MASK] to know only for the sake of talking.
source_info: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal by Montalte, Louis de
title: The Thoughts of Blaise Pascal
prev_sentence: Pride.--Curiosity is mere frivolity.
next_sentence: People would not make voyages if they were never to speak of them, for the sole pleasure of seeing, without hope of ever communicating their impressions.
